Title: Forget 10 Tips. Here are 4 Practical Tips To Improve Your IELTS Speaking Score
Description: Here are 4 most effective and practical ways to improve IELTS speaking skills that I've discovered in my 10+ years as an IELTS Trainer
Article:
For many students, a good IELTS speaking test score is not just a desireâ€”but a necessity. If you're reading this, you likely share that sentiment. Don't worry, you're in good hands. Here are 4 most effective and practical ways to improve IELTS speaking skills that I've discovered in my 10+ years as an IELTS Trainer that would to help you impress the examiner and take your IELTS speaking to the next level.

Note: It makes no difference whether you are taking the exam through IDP or British Council. Both organizations follow the exact same guidelines layed out by the Cambriedge Assessment English organization when assessing a student's performance in the speaking test.

Tip #1: Observe Yourself to simulate the IELTS speaking test

Observation is a powerful tool for self-improvement, and it's no different when it comes to mastering spoken English. Start by recording yourself speaking, in audio or video, through your smartphone.

Doing this provides two exceptional benefits. First, by relistening or re-watching the recordings, you can identify and rectify any pronunciation or other language issues you may have. Secondly, knowing that you're being recorded instills a sense of self-consciousness similar to what you'd experience during the actual speaking test in front of the examiner. This way, you gradually become comfortable with the feeling and perform better under examination conditions.

Tip #2: The JAM Technique For Improving Speaking Test Part 2

The JAM (Just A Minute) Technique, popularized by the BBC radio panel game, is another exceptional tool to improve your spoken English performance. It involves speaking about a given topic without taking the time to think, then listening back to what youâ€™ve said, and finally, re-organizing and re-speaking (check video below for a practical demonstration).

This simple yet effective technique for practicing speaking yields three significant benefits. Firstly, it builds your confidence in speaking at length which is what the ielts examiner is looking for in the cue card section. Secondly, it enhances your ability to organize your thoughts and convey them effectively, which shows the examiner that you deserve a high fluency and coherence score. Lastly, by listening to your own speech, you're able to spot and correct any pronunciation mistakes before the speaking test.

For a deeper understanding of the JAM technique, watch this video demonstration:

Tip #3: Listen To English Conversations for pronunciation and grammatical benefits

While it might be tempting to listen to movies or TV shows to improve your English, these sources may not the best for choice as the dialogues are often too sparse to be of real value. However, listening to English conversations in the form of video interviews or podcasts can be incredibly rich in value.

The benefits of this go beyond improving pronunciation and intonation (more about this in the next tip). It can also aid in expanding your vocabulary and understanding of idiomatic expressions. As a bonus, this can also relieve stress as you can choose to listen to what interests you the most among thousands of podcasts available on a myriad of topics.

Tip #4: Practise That Stress and Intonation and speak english

Understanding and practising stress and intonation is crucial in mastering spoken English. Stress refers to the emphasis placed on certain syllables or words in a sentence, while intonation involves the rising and falling pitch patterns that convey meaning, such as the tone used when asking a question or expressing surprise.

In my decade-long experience, I've observed that even though the official IELTS marking criteria only assigns 25% weightage to stress and intonation in the IELTS speaking test, its impact on overall speaking band scores is far more significant.

The best practice for this is: shadowing. This involves listening to a speech and then trying to mimic it as closely as possible. This exercise helps you to listen carefully and notice changes in stress and intonation. Additionally, your vocal chords get trained to reproduce it.

Here's a useful video for you to get started with shadowing practice:

Just in case it peaked your Interest, here is a brief overview of the marking criteria.

Pronunciation Lexical Resource Grammatical Range and Accuracy Fluency and Coherence Overall Score
This criterion tests the ability to use pronunciation patterns that are understandable to most listeners. This criterion tests the ability to use a wide range of vocabulary appropriately. This criterion tests the ability to use a variety of grammatical structures accurately. This criterion tests the ability to speak at length with natural flow and coherence. This is the average score of the four criteria.
7 8 7 8 7.5

Final Note: IELTS Speaking Test Band Scores Come From English Speaking Skill Development and Not Blind Practice

As a final note, following these tips, with a consistent practice schedule, should significantly boost your IELTS speaking band score come the test day. Remember â€“ practice makes perfect, and every step you take is closer to acing that IELTS test!
